docs.lead_paragraph: Should the government force parents to send their children to classes that may contradict their moral and religious values?

headline.main: Does Sex Ed Undermine Parental Rights?
headline.print_headline: Does Sex Ed Undermine Parental Rights?

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Princeton University professors Robert P George and Melissa Moschella challenges newly mandated sex-education classes that are part of New York City schools chancellor Dennis M Walcott's recommended middle-school curriculum; charges that the mandate undermines parental rights and he insists that families be given the choice to opt out.
docs.snippet: Should the government force parents to send their children to classes that may contradict their moral and religious values?

docs.abstract: Since the recession started, 72 percent of women seeking abortion services have been mothers.
docs.snippet: Since the recession started, 72 percent of women seeking abortion services have been mothers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The subset of women in America who most frequently make use of abortion services, writes Lauren Sandler in Slate this week, are mothers. In 2008, according to the Guttmacher Institute, 61 percent of women who terminated their pregnancies already had at least one child. And in the period since the economic woes of the recession started hitting families, the National Abortion Federation reported to Ms. Sandler, fully 72 percent of clients who came seeking abortion services were mothers.
docs.abstract: Since the recession started, 72 percent of women seeking abortion services have been mothers.
docs.snippet: Since the recession started, 72 percent of women seeking abortion services have been mothers.

headline.main: The Quandary Posed by a New Down Syndrome Test

docs.abstract: Advocates are concerned that a noninvasive test to determine if a fetus has Down syndrome will lead to more pregnancies being terminated.
docs.snippet: Advocates are concerned that a noninvasive test to determine if a fetus has Down syndrome will lead to more pregnancies being terminated.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new test was introduced Monday that can determine if a fetus has Down syndrome using a sample of the mother's blood. The test, and others like it, are expected to reach the market in the coming year and might eventually reduce the need for invasive tests that carry a slight risk of inducing miscarriages.

headline.main: The Quandary Posed by a New Down Syndrome Test

docs.abstract: Will more pregnancies be terminated if women can learn through a simple blood test if they are carrying a baby with Down syndrome?
docs.snippet: Will more pregnancies be terminated if women can learn through a simple blood test if they are carrying a baby with Down syndrome?
